edge: The American independent romantic drama film 'The Room' was written, directed, and produced by Tommy Wiseau, who also stars in the film.

Set in San Francisco, the film 'The Room' is centered around a melodramatic love triangle between amiable banker Johnny (played by Tommy Wiseau), his deceptive fiancée Lisa (played by Juliette Danielle), and his conflicted best friend Mark (played by Greg Sestero).
The deceptive fiancée of Johnny, Lisa is a central character in 'The Room'.
The conflicted best friend of Johnny, Mark is a central character in 'The Room'.
Amiable banker Johnny is played by Tommy Wiseau in 'The Room'.
Lisa is played by Juliette Danielle in 'The Room'.
Mark is played by Greg Sestero in 'The Room'.

Originally shown only in a limited number of California theaters, 'The Room' quickly became a cult film due to its bizarre and unconventional storytelling, technical and narrative issues, and Tommy Wiseau's performance.
'The Room', which was a box-office bomb, became a cult film due to its bizarre and unconventional storytelling, technical and narrative issues, and Tommy Wiseau's performance.

'The Room', which was a box-office bomb, became a cult film due to its bizarre and unconventional storytelling, technical and narrative issues, as well as being written, directed, and produced by Tommy Wiseau.
'The Room' has been labeled as one of the worst films ever made, with some publications describing it as 'the Citizen Kane of bad movies'.
'The Room' has been labeled as one of the worst films ever made, with some publications describing it as 'the Citizen Kane of bad movies'.
In interviews, Juliette Danielle has said that Lisa is based on a real person in Tommy Wiseau's life.
In his book 'The Disaster Artist', Greg Sestero has said that Mark is based on a real person in Tommy Wiseau's life.
According to Juliette Danielle, Lisa is based on a real person in Tommy Wiseau's life.
According to Greg Sestero, Mark is based on a real person in Tommy Wiseau's life.

node_2: money laundering scheme for organized crime
edge: Many of the people involved with the project feared that The Room was part of a money laundering scheme for organized crime.
Wiseau wrote, produced, directed, and starred in The Room.
According to the text material, Wiseau spent the entire US$6,000,00 budget for The Room on production and marketing.

According to The Disaster Artist, Wiseau made numerous poor decisions during filming that unnecessarily inflated the film's budget, such as building sets for sequences that could have been filmed on location, purchasing production equipment rather than renting it, and filming scenes multiple times using different sets.
According to the text material, Wiseau forgot his lines and place on camera, resulting in minutes-long dialogue sequences taking hours or days to shoot.
Wiseau's film required multiple takes for these sequences, leading to significant time and cost overruns.
The extensive shooting times for these scenes contributed significantly to the film's overall production costs, as detailed by Sestero.
The unpredictable behavior of Wiseau during filming caused additional expenses, according to Sestero's account.

In a 2011 Entertainment Weekly article, Schklair announced that he desired credit for directing The Room because Wiseau became too engrossed with his acting duties to direct the film properly and asked him to 'tell the actors what to do, and yell "Action" and "Cut" and tell the cameraman what shots to get.' The script supervisor also said that Wiseau asked Schklair to 'direct [his] movie' but refused to give up the director title.

Schoiklair took charge of numerous sequences in which Wiseau found himself unable to remember lines or adequately interact with the rest of the cast, but left the production before the end of principal photography in favor of another project.
Wiseau is listed as director of The Room.

Despite the film's failure to enjoy immediate success, Wiseau paid to keep the billboard up for over five years, at the cost of US$5,000 a month. This led to the billboard becoming a minor tourist attraction. When asked how he managed to afford to keep the billboard up for so long in such a prominent location, Wiseau responded: 'Well, we like the location, and we like the billboard. So, we feel that people should see The Room.' This suggests that The Room's lack of initial success is related to the concept of Success.

The billboard promoting The Room was kept up for over five years, at a cost of US$5,000 a month, in a prominent location. When asked how he managed to afford to keep the billboard up for so long, Wiseau responded: 'Well, we like the location, and we like the billboard.' This implies that The Room is closely associated with a specific Location.

During its premiere at Laemmle Fairfax and Fallbrook theaters in Los Angeles, The Room's audience laughed at it. Actress Robyn Paris described this. Variety reporter Scott Foundas, who was also in attendance, later wrote that 'most of its viewers to ask for their money back—before even 30 minutes [had] passed.' This shows that The Room and its audience have a close relation.

IFC.com described Wiseau's speaking voice in The Room as 'Borat trying to do an impression of Christopher Walken playing a mental patient.' This implies that there are similarities between Wiseau's speaking voice and Tennessee Williams.
The Guardian described The Room as 'a mix of Tennessee Williams, Ed Wood, and R. Kelly's Trapped in the Closet.' This suggests that there are similarities between The Room and the work of Ed Wood.

The Room was unanimously panned by critics for its poor cinematography.
The Room holds a 24% approval rating based on 33 reviews with an average score of 3.6/10 on the review aggregator Rotten Tomatoes.

The site's critical consensus reads, 'A bona fide classic of midnight cinema, Tommy Wiseau's misguided masterpiece subverts the rules of filmmaking with a boundless enthusiasm that renders such mundanities as acting, screenwriting, and cinematography utterly irrelevant. You will never see a football the same way again.'
The film has a weighted average score of 9 out of 100, based on 5 critics, indicating 'overwhelming dislike' on Metacritic.
The Room was unanimously panned by critics for its poor acting (particularly Wiseau's), screenplay, dialogue, production values, score, direction, and cinematography.
Despite disdain from critics, the film has retrospectively received ironic acclaim from audiences for its perceived shortcomings, with some viewers calling it the 'best worst movie ever'.

In 2013, The Atlantic's Adam Rosen wrote an article titled 'Should Gloriously Terrible Movies Like The Room Be Considered 'Outsider Art'?' where he made the argument 'The label [of outsider art] has traditionally applied to painters and sculptors... but it's hard to see why it couldn't also refer to Wiseau or any other thwarted, un-self-aware filmmaker.'

In a 2017 interview for a Vox video, The Disaster Artist co-writer Tom Bissell explained that according to him, the popularity of The Room can be attributed to various reasons. This highlights the direct relation between the movie and its popularity.
Bissell further explained in the same interview that he personally enjoys watching The Room. This demonstrates the individual's preference for the movie.

The audience at the initial screenings of The Room started encouraging friends to join them for future showings with the intention of mocking the film. This led to a word-of-mouth campaign that resulted in about 100 attending the final screening.
Many of The Room traditions were born during the initial screenings, such as the throwing of spoons and footballs during the film.

Encouraged by the volume of messages received, Wiseau booked a single midnight screening of The Room in June 2004, which proved successful enough that Wiseau booked a second showing in July, and a third in August. These screenings proved to be even more successful and were followed by monthly screenings on the last Saturday of the month, which began selling out and continued up until the theatre was sold in 2012.
Celebrity fans of the film included Paul Rudd, David Cross, Will Arnett, Patton Oswalt, Tim Heidecker, Eric Wareheim, Seth Rogen, and James and Dave Franco.
On the fifth anniversary of the film's premiere, it sold out every screen at the Sunset 5 and both Tommy Wiseau and Greg Sestero did Q&As afterward.

Wiseau is the creator and producer of the film The Room, which has been arranged for screenings in various countries including the United States, Canada, Scandinavia, the United Kingdom, Australia, and New Zealand.
In 2015, Wiseau expressed interest in releasing The Room in Asia.
In January 2018, an official release of The Room was announced for Hong Kong after a group of fans acquired the distribution rights.
The Room was officially released in Taiwan during the 2018 Golden Horse Fantastic Film Festival.
By April 2016, the film had been playing at the Mayfair Theatre in Ottawa, Canada for 80 consecutive months, making it a cult classic.
The Room had regular showings at the Mayfair Theatre in Ottawa, Canada for 80 consecutive months.
The Room had regular showings at a cinema in Ottawa, Canada for 80 consecutive months.
By this date, The Room had been playing at the Mayfair Theatre in Ottawa, Canada for 80 consecutive months.
Audience members dress up as their favorite characters from The Room during screenings, similar to the fan culture surrounding The Rocky Horror Picture Show.
During screenings of The Room, audience members throw plastic spoons in reference to an unexplained framed photo of a spoon on a table in Johnny's living room.
During screenings of The Room, audience members toss footballs to each other from short distances.

Viewers and some of the cast members have viewed The Room as a poorly made drama, while Wiseau claims that it was his intent for audiences to find humor in the film, leading to audience members yelling insulting comments about the quality of the film during screenings.
An interview with Wiseau is included in the DVD's special features, during which he sits directly in front of a fireplace and fails to answer several questions, instead offering non sequiturs.
During the interview included in the DVD's special features, Wiseau sits directly in front of a fireplace with a mantle cluttered by various props from the film.
In April 2011, Wiseau announced plans for a 3D version of The Room, scanned from the 35mm negative.
In 2018, Wiseau revealed his intentions to reshoot The Room in 3D, citing cost-effectiveness reasons.
On September 21, 2018, Wiseau uploaded The Room to YouTube, but it was removed the day after.
On June 27, 2023, Fathom Events theatrically re-released The Room for its 20th anniversary.
Nationwide screenings of The Room were preceded by an exclusive special introduction by Wiseau, reflecting on the film's legacy.

edge: Both memoirs are written by Greg Sestero's co-star and friend Tommy Wiseau. While The Disaster Artist focuses on the making of the movie 'The Room', Yes, I Directed The Room discusses Wiseau's desire to receive credit for directing 'The Room'.
The Canadian documentary about 'The Room' was pulled from theaters due to legal proceedings initiated by Tommy Wiseau, who claimed copyright infringement and invasion of privacy.

node_2: wide release in conjunction with 'the disaster artist'

A remake of 'The Room' with Bob Odenkirk playing Tommy Wiseau's role is currently in post-production.
In September 2010, Newgrounds owner Tom Fulp released a Flash game tribute to 'The Room' in the form of a 16-bit styled adventure game played entirely from Johnny's point of view.
The artwork for the Flash game tribute to 'The Room' was provided by Newgrounds staff member Jeff 'JohnnyUtah' Bandelin.
The music for the Flash game tribute to 'The Room' was transcribed by animator Chris O'Neill from the Mladen Milicevic score and soundtrack.

Although some of the original cast appeared in the series, Tommy Wiseau, Greg Sestero, and Phil Hanzus (Holmes) are not involved.
In 2011, Wiseau mentioned plans for a Broadway adaptation of the film in which he would appear only on opening night.
